parsetree.*:
<root><template><title>RV</title><part><name>type</name>=<value>command

</value></part><part><name index="1"/><value> arma1

</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>1.04

</value></part><part><name>gr1 </name>=<value> Markers

</value></part><part><name>eff</name>=<value> local

</value></part><part><name index="3"/><value> Destroys the given marker.

</value></part><part><name index="4"/><value> '''deleteMarkerLocal''' markerName

</value></part><part><name>p1</name>=<value> markerName: [[String]]

</value></part><part><name index="5"/><value> [[Nothing]]
	  
</value></part><part><name>x1</name>=<value> <code>'''deleteMarkerLocal''' "Marker1"</code> </value></part><part><name/>=<value> Example 
</value></part><part><name>seealso</name>=<value> [[createMarkerLocal]], [[deleteMarker]]
</value></part></template>



<template lineStart="1"><title>GameCategory</title><part><name index="1"/><value>ofpe</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>Scripting Commands</value></part></template>
<template lineStart="1"><title>GameCategory</title><part><name index="1"/><value>arma1</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>Scripting Commands</value></part></template>
<template lineStart="1"><title>GameCategory</title><part><name index="1"/><value>arma2</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>Scripting Commands</value></part></template>
<template lineStart="1"><title>GameCategory</title><part><name index="1"/><value>arma3</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>Scripting Commands</value></part></template>
<template lineStart="1"><title>GameCategory</title><part><name index="1"/><value>tkoh</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>Scripting Commands</value></part></template>

<dl class='command_description'>
<comment><!-- Note Section BEGIN -->
</comment><dd class="notedate">Posted on 7 January, 2012</dd>
<dt class="note">[[User:HomerJohnston|HomerJohnston]]</dt>
<dd class="note">
Unproven: I believe that if you use this command on a globally-created marker, and subsequently another machine executes a global command on the same marker (e.g. setMarkerPos), then the marker will be re-created on the machine it was previously deleted on. Can result in confusing marker behaviour.</root>
